data.name: Native gibberish
data.description:
Compare the following sentences:
```
The only languages which do not change are dead ones.
Nah oato thnlgysne ahaer in eod egolde eug acds wnhc.
```
To any English speaker, the second sentence is complete gibberish, even though this jumble, with the same letters reordered, is identically spaced and punctuated. In fact, this randomness would be apparent to many who don't speak English.

Here are similar examples in various languages, one sentence readable and the next one not:
```
Une langue qui meurt, c’est une vision du monde qui disparaît.
Qne igudcm eto edoni, r’qau îum neisun su tusdi ipr lateeauvn.

Die Grenzen meiner Sprache bedeuten die Grenzen meiner Welt.
Ure Eirtegn znnene Dnhebpr ceaemnie ide Tgwnedz elreem Seir.

Σκεφτείτε όπως σκέφτονται οι σοφοί, αλλά μιλήστε όπως λένε απλοί άνθρωποι.
Τφωωταπνό εσσπ ρίοίαήάιόκ οι οτθτν, ίσφφ μεοσιοπ λάνέ εςτω λικπλ ςαλελεέο.

व्यक्ति अपने विचारों से निर्मित प्राणी है, वह जो सोचता है वही बन जाता है।
तानचने सेप्रों णीतिरा चा हैपहीब सोवह जो, हैजा व अर्है क् व्मि तता यनि वि।
```
_(Note how modifiers like accent marks were not decoupled from the letter they modify. These categories are defined in Unicode.)_

Your program will be provided such an excerpt. The test cases use various forms of ancient writing, often in a language that's no longer spoken. The sentences will be either completely legitimate, or completely scrambled gibberish based on some original text, possibly one carved into stone and sitting in a museum halfway across the world. In a few cases the ancient text is not yet deciphered and its meaning a true mystery.

Your task is to determine if the excerpt you receive is the unmodified original.

Best of luck! `:~)`
